title: The Structure of the Atom
image_desc: A stylized image of an atom with a central nucleus and orbiting electrons.
narration: Welcome to this presentation on the structure of the atom.  We'll explore the key components and how scientists discovered this fundamental building block of matter.

title: The Basic Atomic Model
content:
A small, dense, positively charged nucleus.
Negatively charged electrons orbiting the nucleus.
Mostly empty space.
image_desc: A simple diagram showing a nucleus with a few orbiting electrons, emphasizing the vast empty space within the atom.
narration: The atom is primarily empty space. At its center is a tiny, dense nucleus carrying a positive charge.  Surrounding this nucleus are negatively charged electrons, orbiting at a distance.  Think of it like a solar system, but on a much, much smaller scale.

title: Evidence from Alpha Particle Scattering
content:
Most alpha particles passed straight through the gold foil.
Some alpha particles were deflected at small angles.
A very small number of alpha particles bounced straight back.
image_desc: A diagram showing alpha particles being fired at a thin gold foil, with some passing through, some deflecting, and some bouncing back.
narration: The structure of the atom was confirmed through experiments involving alpha particle scattering. When alpha particles were fired at a thin gold foil, most passed straight through, indicating the atom is mostly empty space.  Some were deflected, suggesting a positive charge repelling them, and a few bounced straight back, revealing the existence of a small, dense, positive nucleus.

title: Components of the Nucleus
content:
**Column 1: Protons**
Positive charge
Mass of approximately 1 atomic mass unit (amu)
**Column 2: Neutrons**
No charge (neutral)
Mass of approximately 1 atomic mass unit (amu)
image_desc: A table summarizing the properties of protons and neutrons.
narration: The nucleus itself is composed of two types of particles: protons and neutrons. Protons carry a positive charge and have a mass of approximately one atomic mass unit. Neutrons, as their name suggests, have no charge but have a similar mass to protons.

title: Atomic Symbols and Nuclide Information
content:
Nucleon number (A): Total number of protons and neutrons.
Proton number (Z): Number of protons.
image_desc: An example of an atomic symbol showing the nucleon number (A) and proton number (Z), for example,  ¹²₆C.
narration: We represent atoms using atomic symbols. The top number, A, is the nucleon number – the total number of protons and neutrons. The bottom number, Z, is the proton number, which tells us the number of protons.  Since atoms are electrically neutral, the number of electrons equals the number of protons.  The number of neutrons is simply A minus Z.

title: Summary
content:
Basic Atomic Model
Alpha Particle Scattering Experiment
Nucleus Components (Protons and Neutrons)
Atomic Symbols and Nuclide Information
image_desc: A simple graphic summarizing the key concepts covered in the presentation.
narration: To summarize, we've covered the basic atomic model, the evidence from alpha particle scattering, the components of the nucleus, and how to interpret atomic symbols to understand the number of protons, neutrons, and electrons in an atom.  Thank you.
